qas.question: During what war did a large number of Italian men first learn standard Italian?
Along with radio and public education, what invention helped to diffuse standard Italian among the Italian population?
In modern Italy, what class of people are regional languages sometimes associated with?
Along with formal settings, where do some Italians avoid speaking their regional language?
Aside from when they're speaking to Italians from their same town or region, where is a common place where Italians speak their regional language?
What language do many Italians speak today as opposed to their regional language?
What is never associated with being lower class?
What is never associated with being uneducated?
What is never associated with being boorish?
What is never associated with being overly informal?

context: In the early 20th century, the vast conscription of Italian men from all throughout Italy during <a0_0>World War I<a0_0/> is credited with facilitating the diffusion of standard Italian among less educated Italian men, as these men from various regions with various regional languages were forced to communicate with each other in a common tongue while serving in the Italian military. With the eventual spread of the radio and <a1_0>television<a1_0/> throughout Italy and the establishment of public education, Italians from all regions were increasingly exposed to standard Italian, while literacy rates among all social classes improved. Today, the majority of Italians are able to <b5_0>speak standard Italian<b5_0/>, though many Italians still speak their regional language regularly or as their primary day-to-day language, especially <a4_0>at home with family<a4_0/> or when communicating with Italians from the same town or region. However, to some Italians, <b6_0><b7_0><b8_0><b9_0>speaking a regional language<b9_0/><b8_0/><b7_0/><b6_0/>, especially in a formal setting or <a3_0>outside of one's region<a3_0/>, may carry a stigma or negative connotations associated with being <a2_0>lower<a2_0/> class, uneducated, boorish, or overly informal.
